STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 6, 2023
Brian Lingle
South Bluff Teaching Family Home
1005 Silver Creek Rd.
Marquette, MI 49855
Re: License #: CI520304229
Dear Mr. Lingle:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on May 9, 2023 . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.

Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee Records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the
following information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(c) Verification of high school diploma or GED when
specified by rule.
Three of four new employee files reviewed lacked verification of high school
d iploma or GED.

CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee Records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the
following information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee
and which are less than 12 months old.
One of four new employee files reviewed lacked the date of one of the references
completed.
Repeat Violation Established: 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 4/29/2022.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee Record.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the
following information prior to employment or at the 7
t ime specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee’s performance
within 30 days of the completion of the probationary
period or within 180 days, whichever is less, and a
written evaluation of the employee’s performance
annually thereafter.
One of three employees that have been employed for over a year did not have
the annual evaluation completed as required.
Repeat Violation Established: 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 4/29/2022.
CCI Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and
volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that
each employee and volunteer who has contact with
residents 4 or more hours per week for more than 2
consecutive weeks is free from communicable
tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable tuberculosis
shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the

last verification or prior to the expiration of the current
verification.
One of four new employees did not have a tuberculosis screening completed prior
to hire as required.
Repeat Violation Established: 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 4/29/2022.
CCI Rule 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(3) The licensee shall document that each staff person
whose function is covered by these rules has
participated in a minimum of 50 clock hours of planned
training within the first year of employment and a
minimum of 25 clock hours of training annually
thereafter related to the employee’s job function. At
least 16 of the 50 hours provided in the first year shall
be orientation provided prior to the assumption of
duties.
One of three employees that have been employed for over a year lacked the
minimum of 25 training hours annually.
C CI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; updated treatment plan.
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and
date an updated treatment plan for each resident at
least once every 90-calendar days following the initial
treatment plan.
One of three current youths files reviewed had an updated treatment plan
c ompleted over 90 days.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Discussed the social service worker completing Updated Treatment Plans on
the correct MDHHS template following the Initial Treatment Plan.
• Provided the facility with the process to request changing internal policy for
annual restraint training hour requirements.
• Discussed the current CAP’s and the facility needing to follow the CAP action
steps. The facility has submitted amendments for CAP’s 2023C000057 and
2023C0000105 that have been approved.

V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Reviewed requirements for dental, educated the facility on the rule indicating if
a dental was completed within twelve months prior to admission to obtain the
documentation of this for the case file.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There was one substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. Special investigation 2023C0000057 dated 1/13/2023.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted three acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period.
The first CAP was in response to special Investigation 2023C0000057 dated
1/13/2023, with a CAP approval dated 2/9/2023, where the facility was found in
non-compliance for Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions (1) (ii),
Rule 400.4131 Compliance with child protection law; development of plan
required, Rule 400.4162 Seclusion within secure and nonsecure facilities (5), and
Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirement; staff qualifications
(4) (a). The facility was found in violation of secluding a youth during this
investigation when seclusion is prohibited. The facility has worked with staff on
verbal de-escalation skills. Staff have been retrained on Mandated Reporter
requirements. Staff have been retrained as well as all team meetings address
seclusion and seclusion being prohibited. There is now a supervisor/ program
manager on the 7am-11pm shift that is working to provide in the moment coaching
and training to direct care workers. The facility has had difficulty meeting the CAP
action step regarding two direct care workers and a supervisor/ program manager
being scheduled daily from 7am-11pm. The facility recently did a CAP
amendment to allow for one direct care worker and a supervisor/ program
manager to be working while youth are in school. The facility has been low staffed
resulting in inability to comply with the CAP action step.
The second CAP was in response to special investigation 2023C0000105 dated
1/13/2023, with a CAP approval dated 2/9/2023, where the facility was found in
non-compliance for Rule 400.4109 Program Statement (1) (c), Rule 400.4159
Youth Restraint (5), and Rule 400.4160 Emergency Restraints (c). The facility has
addressed concerns regarding staff boundaries by retraining staff and addressing
boundary concerns at team meetings. The facility has been reviewing restraint
video footage within 24 hours of restraints occurring and meeting with staff
involved to discuss the restraint and provide feedback. Since this CAP was
implemented, the facilities Handle with Care trainer has left the facility and a new
trainer was recently hired. The facility has had difficulty meeting the CAP action
step regarding two direct care workers and a supervisor/ program manager being

scheduled daily from 7am-11pm. The facility recently did a CAP amendment to
allow for one direct care worker and a supervisor/ program manager to be working
while youth are in school. The facility has been low staffed resulting in inability to
comply with the CAP action step.
The third CAP was in response to special investigation 2023C0000279 dated
4/10/2023, with a CAP approval dated 5/5/2023), where the facility was found in
non-compliance for Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedure (1) (e).
Special investigation 2022C0227004 dated 6/23/2022 placed the facility on a
provisional license and has been successfully completed and closed. This CAP
was completed in January 2023. This CAP addressed the facility being found in
non-compliance for Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff and Rule 400.4127 Staff to
resident ratio (4). The facility implemented a crisis protocol for staff that allowed
staff to be able to contact an on-call supervisor due to supervisors not being onsite
in the evening hours during this CAP. As a result of this CAP, supervisors were
scheduled Monday through Friday from 7am to 5pm and program managers from
3pm to 11pm. Staff reviewed youth safety plans in order to know steps to take
during crisis situations. Team meetings addressed individual youths’
noncompliance and addressed ways for staff to address noncompliance. The
facility implemented a search of youth and belongings upon youth returning from
unsupervised off grounds activities such as school to limit contraband items
brought into the facility. Varying interval not to exceed fifteen-minute protocol was
reviewed with staff as well as supervisors reviewed logs to ensure checks were
occurring as required.
Financial Overview
Teaching Family Homes annual third-party audit report for fiscal year ending
September 30, 2021, was reviewed by the Bureau of Audit, and resulting in
concerning financial condition. The results of the audit reported a negative total net
asset, negative working capital, a deficit of unrestricted net assets, and a ratio of
0.54:1. The facility made some progress as the amount of negative total assets,
working capital, operating ratio, and unrestricted net assets are less than they
were in the previous 2020 audit however, the factors continue to indicate that the
facility is in a declining financial condition. A special investigation addressed these
concerns (Special Investigation 2022C0128036). During the Special Investigation,
documents were obtained including accounts Receivable Aging Summary as of
July 12, 2022, accounts Payable Aging Summary as of July 12, 2022, PPP Loan
Forgiveness documentation which reported loan forgiveness dated 5/4/2022,
statement of cash flows for October 2021 through June 2022, synergy applications
for the CARES program. These documents were provided to the Bureau of Audit
for further review. After review by the Bureau of Audit, the total net assets are
positive, and the working capital are positive with these changes. The Manager of
Audit and Review was not able to fully determine if the facility is completely stable
with this limited information. The annual third-party audit report for fiscal year
ending September 30, 2022, has not yet been issued for year.

Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment documents the facilities action steps to come into compliance and
maintain compliance with prior rule violations. The current Chief Administrator
notes the difficulties in maintaining the roles as both Chief Administrator and
Therapist. The facility is in the process of changing Chief Administrators. The
current Chief Administrator and new proposed Chief Administrator both report the
facility has seen improvements with the corrective action plans in placed however
low staffing remains to be a concern. The facility does have a preservice
scheduled for the middle of May and are hoping to have more direct care workers
hired. There has been noted improvement with having supervisors on shift to
mentor and provide in the moment coaching to direct care workers. There has
been transition during this review period with the facility having a supervisor leave
as well as the Residential Director/ Trainer.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Three employees were interviewed during the onsite visit. All employees reported
feeling safe and supported in their job duties. There were no concerns noted by
employees.
Three youth were interviewed during onsite visit. The youth interviewed reported
feeling safe, feeling respected, and treated well by staff. All the youth are
attending school. Youth reported receiving three meals a day and snacks. Youth
reported they have clean cloths and bedding. The youth did not report any
concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility was completed during the onsite visit. The facility
was clean, and no safety concerns were noted. Medications and cleaning
chemicals are stored appropriately. All bedrooms had appropriate bedding. The
kitchen was clean with the menu posted on the refrigerator. The facility had
emergency plans posted and the intent to check criminal history posted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
05/22/2023

Jennifer Pastorick Date
Licensing Consultant

May 22, 2023
